title: How to Replace a Door Sill

steps.title: Measure the existing door threshold for length and width.
steps.content: Measure the existing door threshold for length and width.

steps.title: Purchase a metal sill of the same size and shape.
steps.content: Purchase a metal sill of the same size and shape.

steps.title: Use a variable speed drill fitted with a screwdriver bit to remove the screws anchoring the threshold into place.
steps.content: Use a variable speed drill fitted with a screwdriver bit to remove the screws anchoring the threshold into place. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Use a utility knife to cut through any caulk on the front and back edges of the sill.
steps.content: Use a utility knife to cut through any caulk on the front and back edges of the sill.

steps.title: Place the end of a pry bar beneath the threshold and pull up on the bar to pull the old threshold away from the door frame.
steps.content: Place the end of a pry bar beneath the threshold and pull up on the bar to pull the old threshold away from the door frame. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Lay the new threshold out on a flat surface and place the old one on top of it.
steps.content: Lay the new threshold out on a flat surface and place the old one on top of it. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Use a pencil to trace the shape of the ends of the old threshold onto the new one.
steps.content: Use a pencil to trace the shape of the ends of the old threshold onto the new one. Most metal thresholds are cut to fit around the door jamb. Because each door jamb can be different in size, the threshold must be cut on site to fit. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Remove the old threshold and screw the new threshold down onto a work table to keep it from moving.
steps.content: Remove the old threshold and screw the new threshold down onto a work table to keep it from moving. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Use a jigsaw to cut out the shape of the door jambs from the ends of the new threshold.
steps.content: Use a jigsaw to cut out the shape of the door jambs from the ends of the new threshold. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Test the fit of the new threshold beneath the door and make sure the door closes over it.
steps.content: Test the fit of the new threshold beneath the door and make sure the door closes over it.

steps.title: Screw the new threshold into place.
steps.content: Screw the new threshold into place.

steps.title: Run a bead of waterproof caulk along the front and back edges of the threshold to help seal it into place.
steps.content: Run a bead of waterproof caulk along the front and back edges of the threshold to help seal it into place. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Remove the door casings on either side of the doorway.
steps.content: Remove the door casings on either side of the doorway.

steps.title: Insert the end of a pry bar behind the casings and gently tug them free.
steps.content: Insert the end of a pry bar behind the casings and gently tug them free. Set them aside for later. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Use a circular saw to cut the threshold into three pieces.
steps.content: Use a circular saw to cut the threshold into three pieces. Cut nearly to the bottom of the threshold, but do not cut all the way through to avoid cutting the toe kick. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Cut the rest of the way through the threshold with a handsaw for control.
steps.content: Cut the rest of the way through the threshold with a handsaw for control.

steps.title: Insert a pry bar beneath each section of the threshold and pull it free.
steps.content: Insert a pry bar beneath each section of the threshold and pull it free. If any section is not coming free easily, use a hammer and chisel to break it into pieces before prying it up. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Measure the length of the door sill and ensure that the new threshold is of equal size.
steps.content: Measure the length of the door sill and ensure that the new threshold is of equal size. Cut the new threshold to fit with a circular saw if necessary.

steps.title: Slide the new threshold into place to ensure that it fits.
steps.content: Slide the new threshold into place to ensure that it fits.

steps.title: Paint the new threshold with a water and UV proof stain to help protect it from the elements.
steps.content: Paint the new threshold with a water and UV proof stain to help protect it from the elements. Allow it to dry. Alternatively, coat the new sill with 2 coats of clear polyurethane to seal the wood.

steps.title: Slide the new threshold back into place.
steps.content: Slide the new threshold back into place.

steps.title: Drill pilot holes into the threshold that are slightly smaller than the finish nails that will hold it in place.
steps.content: Drill pilot holes into the threshold that are slightly smaller than the finish nails that will hold it in place. This will prevent the threshold from cracking as you drive in the new nails. [11] X Research source

steps.title: Hammer in the finish nails to hold the threshold in place.
steps.content: Hammer in the finish nails to hold the threshold in place.

steps.title: Fill the nail holes with wood putty.
steps.content: Fill the nail holes with wood putty.

steps.title: Reattach the casings on either side of the doorway.
steps.content: Reattach the casings on either side of the doorway.

steps.title: Hammer the finish nails back into place to reinstall the casings.
steps.content: Hammer the finish nails back into place to reinstall the casings.
